com.google.publicalerts.cap.testing

Class MockTrustStrategy

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.publicalerts.cap.testing.MockTrustStrategy
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TrustStrategy

    public class MockTrustStrategy
extends java.lang.Object
implements TrustStrategy
    A testing implementation of TrustStrategy that defaults to skipping all validation.

    • Method Detail

      • allowMissingSignatures

        public boolean allowMissingSignatures()
        Description copied from interface: TrustStrategy
        Return false if valid digital signatures are always required. Return true if a missing digital signature or Public Key should be tolerated. When both signature and Public Key are available, they will always be validated irrespective of this configuration setting.
        Specified by:
        allowMissingSignatures in interface TrustStrategy

      • allowUntrustedCredentials

        public boolean allowUntrustedCredentials()
        Description copied from interface: TrustStrategy
        Return false if we must always have explicit trust in the credentials used to validate a digital signature (as defined by TrustStrategy.isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey)). Return true if untrusted credentials should be tolerated.
        Specified by:
        allowUntrustedCredentials in interface TrustStrategy

      • isKeyTrusted

        public boolean isKeyTrusted(java.security.PublicKey key)
        Description copied from interface: TrustStrategy
        Return true if the given PublicKey should be trusted in the context of validating the digital signatures of CAP alerts. Normally this would mean ensuring the PublicKey can be associated with an explicitly trusted 3rd party, e.g. via the use of X.509 certificates. Return false if the given PublicKey is not trusted. Note this method may be called irrespective of the return value of TrustStrategy.allowUntrustedCredentials()
        Specified by:
        isKeyTrusted in interface TrustStrategy
